constellations_other.name: Lois Weber and the split-screen
constellations_other.description: Lois Weber was the third filmmaker to use split screens to show simultaneous action, helping establish it as part of cinematic language, particularly its use in thrillers. It's since been taken to extremes by auteurs and videogames.

results.title: Donzoko = The Lower depths
results.creator_credit: Toho Kabushiki Kaisha, Shojiro Motoki and Akira Kurosawa
results.brief_description:
Gorky’s classic proletarian drama about human flotsam in a Moscow dosshouse living on illusions was revived by Kurosawa who injected new meaning into the adaptation of theatre to cinema. The film remains faithful to the text while transplanting the play into Tokyo of the Edo period. Kurosawa consciously brings out the humour not normally associated with the play but inherent in the gap between illusion and reality at the play’s centre. The Edo setting is deliberately ironic because it is a period that is usually romanticised by the Japanese. ‘The Lower Depths’ was filmed on only two sets but Kurosawa reconstitutes theatrical space in cinematic terms while retaining a deliberate theatricality in the use of sound and especially in performance. Acting is presentational rather than interpretational. Multiple cameras allowed the actors to maintain some continuity of performance (see also High and Low). See also, the version directed by Jean Renoir in 1936 (held in our collection). Also available on 16mm.

Credits: Producers, Shojiro Moroki, Akira Kurosawa ; director, Akira Kurosawa ; script, Hideo Oguni, Akira Kurosawa ; photography, Ichio Yamasaki ; music, Masaru Sato.
Cast: Toshiro Mifune, Isuzu Yamada, Ganjiro Nakamura.

results.title: Donnie Darko [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Flower Films, Pandora Cinema, Adam Fields, Nancy Juvonen, Sean McKittrick and Richard Kelly
results.brief_description: The titular character of “Donnie Darko” is a troubled teenager who sleepwalks, suffers from apparant schizophrenia, struggles with his familial relations and is beset by visions of a six-foot demonic rabbit. The setting is 1988 and Donnie lives with his sympathetic parents and two sisters; a boy with friends, he is bullied by several school thugs and forms an attraction to a new girl in town, Gretchen. Donnie’s troubles multiply when the giant rabbit, named Frank, summons him from his bed one evening informing him that the world will end in approximately 28 days. Given that when he returns home his bedroom has been crushed by a falling aeroplane engine, Donnie suspects that Frank may be on to something. For the remainder of the film then, Donnie must try to make sense of this prophecy whilst fighting the sinister forces that compel him to commit acts of vandalism. Blending elements of the horror genre and the teenage coming-of-age flick, “Donnie Darko” also covers issues such as parenthood, sibling relationships, young love, time travel, destiny, student-teacher relations, paedophilia, conservatism in school curriculum, psychoanalysis, psychosis and imaginary friends. But “Donnie Darko” is more than just a clever pastiche of genre-awareness scenarios and a hip/clever postmodern appropriation of film-school inspirations; the film surpasses these limitations with a view that is creative, passionate, compelling and defiantly original.

results.title: Donnie Brasco [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Mandalay Entertainment, Mark Johnson, Barry Levinson, Louis Digiamo, Gail Mutrux and Mike Newell
results.brief_description: This is a gangster movie quite like no other which is more concerned with character study, friendship and betrayal. Donnie Brasco (Johnny Depp), also known as Joe the Jeweller, befriends Mafia small man and former assassin Lefty Ruggiero (Al Pacino). Lefty sees in the young Donnie a chance to rise in the Mafia ranks, something the aging Lefty, with his drug addicted son and passive wife is no longer capable of. Unbeknown to Lefty, Donnie Brasco is an under cover special agent, working with the FBI to infiltrate the New York Mafia underworld. What at first seems a simple case of undercover work is complicated by Donnie’s genuine feelings of friendship towards Lefty and Lefty’s loyalty towards Donnie. Based on the book by Joseph D. Pistone with Richard Woodley. Also starring Michael Madsen, Bruno Kirby, James Russo and Anne Heche.

results.title: Donna Karan. Vivienne Westwood
results.creator_credit: Video Fashion, Michelle Brown, Yana Gould, Lida Piompino and Rebecca Reeder
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Designers”.
Donna Karan: U.S. designer Donna Karan discusses the trademarks of her signature brand and DKNY - luxury, comfort, sensuality, strength and femininity to create a timeless look that transcends any fashion trends - defined by the narrator as a combination of modern luxury and American sensibility. Karan’s history as a designer is covered, as well as interviews with fashion magazine editors, models, fans and photographers. “Vivienne Westwood”: Britain’s most controversial designer is undoubtedly Vivienne Westwood, a designer who attracts responses such as innovative, controversial, sexy and unorthodox. Westwood - normally reticent about discussing issues such as fashion talks about her relationship with Malcolm MacLaren in the 70’s, the breakup and change in focus to the deconstruction of garments, and her passion for the 17-19th centuries. Like the section on Donna Karan, the narrator attempts to capture the tenets of Westwood’s design and looks at areas such as the corset, platform shoes, distorting the female form and symbols of bondage. Both feature plenty of catwalk footage of the designs in action.

results.title: Donkeys
results.brief_description: Shows the physical and behavioural characteristics of adult and young donkeys which are closely observed in this non-narrated film. Also features close-up studies of individual details, with a soundtrack of music and natural sounds. Suitable for primary school level.

results.title: Done Bali
results.creator_credit: Negara Productions, Kerry Negara, Tony Chapman and Paul Cox
results.brief_description: This program looks at the history of Bali, including the commercialisation of it’s culture, tourism and the impact of Western influences upon such things as education. It examines the role played by tourism as an agent of change, and questions the inevitability of change upon this small island.

results.title: Donatello 1386-1466: the first modern sculptor
results.creator_credit: BBC, RM Arts and Ann Turner
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Donatello is said in this documentary to be the most versatile and imaginative of all artists of his century and he is credited with bringing the Renaissance to Italy. The intense and personal work of Donatello is examined here in terms of his vision, emotion and techniques. Most notable is his inventive techniques in his work such as was used in his relief making sculpture. Writer and art historian Charles Avery locates an obscure terra-cotta relief of Donatello’s in Florence and throughout the documentary the authentication of the work is shown. Avery discusses the work of Donatello along with sculptors Henry Moore, Elisabeth Frink, and Peter Rockwell. This documentary was made shortly after the restoration of a number of significant works by Donatello and is the first time that these works can be seen in their former glory revealing a brilliance in colour and detail not seen in recent history.
